description: Before 1000 CE - From Middle English grinnen, from Old English grennian, of Germanic origin and probably related to groan. Compare to Old High German grennan (“to mutter”) and Danish grine (“to show one's teeth, to laugh”)

entries.meaning: A smile in which the lips are parted to reveal the teeth.
examples: When my son appeared at the door the next day with his schoolbag on his back, the Professor broke into a wide grin and opened his arms to embrace him.

verbs.description: grin (third-person singular simple present grins, present participle grinning, simple past and past participle grinned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To smile, parting the lips so as to show the teeth.
examples: Why do you grin?  Did I say something funny?
She grinned pleasure at his embarrassment.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, dated) To show the teeth, like a snarling dog.
(transitive) To grin as part of producing a particular facial expression, such as a smile or sneer.
examples: He grinned a broad smile when I told him the result.
He grinned a cruel sneer when I begged him to stop.
Like a bridde that hasteth to the grynne.
